content.prompt: Assume good Z is produced in a competitive output market that is in long-run equilibrium. In the short run, the variable input is unskilled labor whose wage is determined in a competitive labor market. Suppose there is an increase in consumer demand for good Z. Which of the following explains the resulting change in the labor market for unskilled workers in the short run?

choices.label: New firms will enter using more labor and more capital to produce good Z, lowering the price of good Z.
With more output of good Z produced, the supply of labor needed to produce good Z increases, and the wage rate for unskilled workers will fall.
The price of good Z increases and the labor demand curve shifts to the right along the existing labor supply curve, resulting in higher wages and employment of unskilled workers.
Since the market is in long-run equilibrium, economic profits are zero, and therefore the demand for labor remains unchanged.
The marginal factor cost of labor will decrease, leading to more unskilled workers being hired.

topic.text: 5.2: Changes in Factor Demand and Factor Supply
